article.title: Quantum phase transition with dissipative frustration

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the blue box represent in this diagram of the 1D quantum phase model?
choices: A bath coupled linearly to the phase difference Δφ<sub>n</sub>
A bath coupled linearly to the conjugated momentum of the phase
The Josephson junction with energy E<sub>J</sub>

multiple_choice_question.text: What physical quantity is represented by the resistance R<sub>g</sub> in this chain of superconducting islands?
choices: Dissipative coupling for the difference of the superconducting phases
Dissipative coupling in the charge Q<sub>n</sub>

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the non-monotonic behavior of the critical line in this phase diagram indicate?
choices: The ordered phase is always favored by increasing dissipation.
Increasing total dissipation always leads to a disordered phase.
For a given ratio of dissipative coupling strengths, the system can transition from ordered to disordered and back to ordered by increasing dissipation.
The system only exhibits a phase transition in the presence of conventional dissipation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the solution of this self-consistent equation, V<sub>sc</sub>, represent?
choices: The bare energy constant of the potential
The critical value of the parameter g
